title: 2. The Brainstem and Long Tract Signs

vectorData.altText: 19C   The Brainstem and Long Tract Signs

White matter tracts pass into and through the brainstem. Damage to tracts passing through the brainstem affects information flow up or down the CNS. This causes long-tract signs, in which the signs of the lesion are located in a body part far from the lesion     . As a reminder of the three tracts you’ve learned:
Some tracts carry motor information downward. The corticobulbar tract brings motor commands from primary motor cortex to the brainstem nuclei associated with certain cranial nerves. The corticospinal tract carries motor commands from primary motor cortex through the brainstem to its point of decussation at the spinomedullary junction, and from there into the lateral column of spinal white matter      . 
Some tracts carry sensory information upward. The spinothalamic tract carries pain and temperature information from the contralateral body into the brainstem, where it is joined by the same sensory modalities from the contralateral face, before ascending to primary somatosensory cortex via the thalamus     . The dorsal columns carry fine touch, conscious proprioception and vibration sense from the ipsilateral body to the spinomedullary junction, where this information decussates to form the medial lemniscus. The medial lemniscus, now carrying information from the contralateral body, receives the same modalities from the contralateral face, and brings it to primary somatosensory cortex via the thalamus     .
Lesions of the brainstem can affect one or more of these tracts resulting in contralateral long-tract signs    , such as contralateral paralysis of the body and / or face, or contralateral loss of sensory modalities in the body and / or face. 
How does the clinician localize a lesion, using the neurological exam, to the brainstem? Read on…
signs resulting from a lesion of a white matter tract, which can manifest in regions of the body far removed from the lesion.
e.g. a brainstem lesion can cause paralysis of the foot
The brainstem lesion illustrated would cause an UMN-type motor deficit in the contralateral face and body.
The CST Passes Through the Brainstem
The Spinothalamic Tract Passes Through the Brainstem
The brainstem lesion illustrated would cause a loss of nociception and temperature sensation in the contralateral face and body.
The brainstem lesion illustrated would cause a loss of fine touch sensation in the contralateral face and body.
The DC/ML Passes Through the Brainstem
